name: eupick
params: setvar s0, wff w0, wff w1
body: |- wi(wa(weu(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1))), wi(w0, w1))

stmt.origin: sylan(weu(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1)), wi(w0, w1), wmo(s0, w0))

body.origin:
|- wi(wa(weu(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1))), wi(w0, w1))
-| wi(weu(s0, w0), wmo(s0, w0))
-| wi(wa(wmo(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1))), wi(w0, w1))

cumulated.origin:
|- wi(wa(weu(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1))), wi(w0, w1))
-| wi(weu(s0, w0), wmo(s0, w0))
-| wi(wa(wmo(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1))), wi(w0, w1))

|- wi(wa(weu(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1))), wi(w0, w1))
-| wi(wa(wmo(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1))), wi(w0, w1))

body.origin: |- wi(wa(wmo(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1))), wi(w0, w1))

cumulated.origin: |- wi(wa(weu(s0, w0), wex(s0, wa(w0, w1))), wi(w0, w1))

comment: Existential uniqueness "picks" a variable value for which another wff is true. If there is only one thing ` x ` such that ` ph ` is true, and there is also an ` x ` (actually the same one) such that ` ph ` and ` ps ` are both true, then ` ph ` implies ` ps ` regardless of ` x ` . This theorem can be useful for eliminating existential quantifiers in a hypothesis. Compare Theorem *14.26 in [WhiteheadRussell] p. 192. (Contributed by NM, 10-Jul-1994.)
